image.altText: A big town sign in the NT saying Elliott with a petrol station in the background

items.synopsis: Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest used to be lead investment partners on the $30 billion Sun Cable project. Now, they're bidding against each other to control it in a closed-door process close to resolution.

title.children: 'Get your act together': A town's message to Australia's two richest men as they struggle for control over solar farm

image.altText: Man in a yellow hoodie standing next to a protester holding a sign shouting.

items.synopsis: At this stage, the UK government won't say how much it's spending on the coronation, but some estimates put it at between $90-180 million — while a recent poll found 51 per cent of Brits believed the coronation shouldn't be taxpayer-funded.

title.children: King Charles III's immense wealth questioned as coronation sparks protests

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: Confused about where we're headed and why we appear to be hurtling headlong towards a self-induced recession? You're in good company, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: The RBA has just relit community anger over its messaging

image.altText: Grady in a crowd, between two women holding signs that read "staff working conditions are student learning conditions".

items.synopsis: University tutors who say they cannot plan for their futures are among the thousands of university staff to walk off the job as part of a national week of action against insecure work and wage theft.

title.children: 'Anger and discontent' on campus 'the worst in decades' as university staff walk off the job over casualisation

image.altText: Jana Pittman, smiling widely, wearing floral shirt and black jacket, with garden shrubs in the background.

items.synopsis: When the media turned on her after the 2004 Athens Olympics, Jana Pittman was filled with self-doubt, and it wasn't the first time. Here's how she turned things around.

title.children: Jana Pittman is a former world champion, a mum of six and a doctor. But her 'greatest success' is something else

image.altText: The Australian taxpayer-backed Future Fund has invested in Adani

items.synopsis: International pressure led to Adani vowing to cut ties with Myanmar's military junta in 2021. Now, leaked documents reveal how the resources giant had been privately negotiating coal ventures with the sanctioned regime leaders.

title.children: 'They've misled the public': Leaked letters reveal mining giant Adani was 'enthused' to work with military dictatorship

image.altText: Vladimir Putin, wearing a dark suit, looks ahead as he sits in front of green, white, blue and red banners.

items.synopsis: Moscow is accusing Ukraine of attacking the Kremlin with drones in what it is calling a failed bid to kill Russian President Vladimir Putin.

title.children: Russia flags 'retaliatory measures' after claiming Ukraine tried to assassinate Putin with drones

image.altText: A light ball above the Kremlin Senate.

items.synopsis: While Ukraine has on occasion struck targets on Russian territory, a direct assault on the Kremlin, a fortified complex in the heart of Moscow, would be its most audacious attack by far.

title.children: Did Ukraine try to kill Putin or could the drone attack on the Kremlin have been a false flag?

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a blue suit and red tie as he speaks into a microphone at a convention.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump denies raping writer E. Jean Carroll in a deposition video that has been played for a jury in a civil trial where the former US president is seeking to defend himself without testifying in person.

title.children: Donald Trump calls rape allegation 'ridiculous' in video played for jury

image.altText: The side of a builder leaning against a timber house frame

items.synopsis: The federal government still does not have enough support to pass its housing future fund but has won over another two votes, as they strike a deal to guarantee the fund will help to build at least 1,200 new homes in each state and territory in the next five years.

title.children: $10 billion housing fund to include minimum build guarantee, as government continues to search for support

image.altText: Rhiannon, wearing a black hoodie, stands against a blue wall. She is looking into a window. Her image is reflected back at her.

items.synopsis: With the national rental vacancy rate at a record low for a fourth straight month, welfare workers say they are seeing more and more people being pushed into homelessness.

title.children: A rental market 'firmly locked in favour of landlords' is pushing tenants into homelessness

image.altText: Two men smile in an image composite.

items.synopsis: One of two SA police officers stabbed at Crystal Brook yesterday by a man who was then shot dead remains in a critical but stable condition after undergoing surgery, while the other is "recovering well", the state's police commissioner says.

title.children: Stabbed SA policeman undergoes surgery but still critical, other officer 'recovering well'

image.altText: A long train snakes along the railway line somewhere near Parkes.

items.synopsis: The Inland Rail project from Melbourne to Brisbane was originally due to be completed in 2025. But with construction yet to get underway anywhere in Queensland, some are asking whether the entire project will ever be finished.

title.children: 'It will never get to Brisbane': Inland Rail project at a crossroads

image.altText: A close-up of a woman vaping, blowing out a big cloud of smoke.

items.synopsis: The state government has already put thousands of retailers "on notice", but concerns remain around how cracking down on the sale of illegal vapes is enforced.

title.children: 'I'm at a loss': Parent pleads for enforcement as WA government promises 'crackdown' on vapes

image.altText: A scooter rider can be seen travelling down a bike path, followed by a police officer on a motorbike wearing body-cam.

items.synopsis: Video shows officers on motorbikes pursuing James Cole at high speed on a busy road and bike paths as the 38-year-old tries to evade them.

title.children: 'Please, it's Christmas and that': E-scooter rider pleads with police after 100kph chase along Canberra bike paths

image.altText: A hand resting above a calculator

items.synopsis: There is a growing sense of urgency around Australia's tax problems ahead of next week's budget.

title.children: The big tax problems next week's budget likely won't tackle

image.altText: An electric truck charging station in the US

items.synopsis: Switching to zero-emission trucks would be the fastest way to cut emissions, but they've largely been left out of the national EV strategy. Here's what's holding back the uptake.

title.children: A single urban delivery truck emits as much as several passenger vehicles. So why aren't they electric?

image.altText: Gold medalist Tori Bowie of the United States poses with her medal.

items.synopsis: The athletics world is mourning a star gone too young, with American sprinter, three-time Olympic medallist and 2017 100m world champion Tori Bowie found dead at age 32.

title.children: Tori Bowie was a star at the 2016 Rio Olympic Games, now the world champion sprinter is dead at age 32

image.altText: NT A composite image of Police Minister Kate Worden and high profile AFL figure Eddie McGuire next to each other

items.synopsis: The high-profile Melbourne commentator is invited to travel to the NT before making future comments about its social problems.

title.children: AFL personality Eddie McGuire criticised for 'potshot' comment about Northern Territory social woes

image.altText: A Richmond forward roars in triumph as his teammates surround him after a goal at the MCG.

items.synopsis: A week after a Hawks star says he can't imagine living in Tasmania, Jack Riewoldt says players will move there because it has similar lifestyle benefits to Geelong.

title.children: 'There is plenty of farmland': Why Tigers champ believes new Tassie team will entice players

image.altText: A cast of cartoon characters.

items.synopsis: The Devils? How about the Tasmania Apples? Or maybe the Penguins? The search has begun for a name for Tassie's new AFL team — and one early favourite may require some wheeling and dealing to secure.

title.children: Is 'Tasmanian Devils' tied up with Warner Bros? What other options are there for a Tassie AFL team name?

image.altText: A person climbing up a pole with a sign saying "no gas at JPP"

items.synopsis: A decade after conflict at James Price Point prompted Woodside to abandon its gas hub plans for the region, another energy giant is looking at establishing a floating LNG facility off the coast.

title.children: New gas project looms 10 years after historic protests killed Woodside refineries in Kimberley

image.altText: Four people stand on a concrete outdoor floor. They are holding red and white signs with ant-fracking slogans on them

items.synopsis: Northern Territory Chief Minister Natasha Fyles says her government met all the recommendations of a key inquiry before approving fracking. Some analysts disagree.

title.children: Critics dispute NT government's claim it met all fracking inquiry promises

image.altText: A man in glasses stands in front of microphones, speaking.

items.synopsis: New South Wales Nationals leader Paul Toole says there will be repercussions if party member Ben Franklin accepts an upper house president role, offered to him by close friend Premier Chris Minns.

title.children: Nationals leader won't rule out expulsion over Ben Franklin president offer

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: The US Federal Reserve raises interest rates by another 0.25 of a percentage point, to more than 5 per cent, leading to a fall on share markets. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US Federal Reserve raises interest rates sending Wall St lower; ASX to follow

schema.headline: Live: US Federal Reserve raises interest rates sending Wall St lower; ASX to follow

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Fed raises rates, sinks Wall Street
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The big news globally overnight was the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to between 5-5.25%. The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with the S & P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%. Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent. "Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. " "Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports. "Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation. "Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Nassim Khadem and myself will be taking you through today's market action along with news from across the ABC Business Reporting Team. Plenty of news around with a Fed rates decision and NAB's profit result. Join us to stay across all of it throughout the day.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: US Federal Reserve raises interest rates sending Wall St lower; ASX to follow

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 9:20am AEST

The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with the S & P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%. Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent. "Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. " "Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports. "Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation. "Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed raises rates, sinks Wall Street

children.content: The big news globally overnight was the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to between 5-5.25%.
The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes.
US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with the S
P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%.
Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent.

"Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. "

"Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports.

"Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation.
"Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts."

Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent. "Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports. "Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation. image.altText: A scene from Guardians of the Galaxy shows three characters on a spaceship, walking as though they are on a mission.

items.synopsis: Chris Pratt, Bradley Cooper and Zoe Saldaña return for this redemptive final instalment of the MCU trilogy from writer-director James Gunn.

title.children: Guardians of the Galaxy 3 is genuinely funny, surprisingly soulful — and very weird

image.altText: Jess Nobleza

items.synopsis: Brought in to funnel students into degrees that would address Australia's skill shortages, the Job Ready Graduate package slashed the student contribution of some degrees while hiking others, but enrolments in the arts is still popular, universities claim.

title.children: Calls for fee structures to be revisited for humanities degrees as enrolments remain popular

image.altText: Lord Simon Woolley and King Charles walking together.

items.synopsis: Despite the multicultural and multi-faith makeup of modern Britain, the coronation of King Charles III will be a deeply Christian affair. But the holiest moment of the ceremony, a tradition "akin to priestly ordination", won't be broadcast.

title.children: King Charles's coronation will feature a ritual from biblical times — but you won't see it

image.altText: Jair Bolsonaro looks on after a ceremony about the National Policy for Education at the Planalto Palace in Brasilia.

items.synopsis: Brazilian police are investigating how the former far-right leader — a strident coronavirus sceptic who vowed never to get a COVID-19 vaccine — was registered as vaccinated in health records made public in February.

title.children: Brazilian police raid former president's home amid probe into false COVID record

image.altText: Police standing around a street with several ambulance in the background

items.synopsis: The seventh-grade student is arrested as police investigate the motive behind the shooting.

title.children: Serbian teenager 'had a list' of those he wanted to kill in rampage that left nine dead

image.altText: Two men in traditional Indian dress sit next to each other as part of a same-sex marriage union.

items.synopsis: India's Hindu nationalist government and religious leaders are staunchly opposing same-sex marriage as a landmark case plays out in the country's Supreme Court, but others say there is nothing to fear.

title.children: 'Complete havoc': How could legalising same-sex marriage play out in conservative India?
